title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate Safety and Efficacy of MEM 1003 in Patients With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine in a 12-week treatment study if MEM 1003 is a safe and effective treatment for patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.
description_detailed:
Alzheimer's disease is the leading cause of dementia and one of the most common diseases of the aging population. It is a chronic brain disease that involves gradual memory loss, decline in the ability to perform routine tasks, disorientation, difficulty in learning, loss of language skills, impairment of judgment, and personality changes in affected individuals. The neurodegenerative nature of the disease eventually leads to the failure of other organ systems and death.

Perturbations in calcium homeostasis in the central nervous system, such as those associated with Alzheimer's disease and aging as well as stroke and head trauma can result in an increase in intracellular levels of calcium (Ca2+). Increased levels of Ca2+ may lead to cellular dysregulation and cell death. The role of calcium in these neurodegenerative processes led to the hypothesis that controlling calcium levels may be beneficial, particularly where progressive neuronal damage results in cognitive dysfunction and memory loss.

MEM 1003 is the (+)-enantiomer of a dihydropyridine that has been optimized for central nervous system activity. It inhibits L-type Ca2+ channels and within the anticipated human dosing range has more benign cardiovascular effects than other DHP L-Type calcium channel modulators.
drug: MEM 1003 (aka MEM-1003; BAY Z 4406) — investigational small-molecule L‑type calcium channel modulator
explanation_target: Reason: The description/trial title refer to MEM 1003 as a therapy for mild–moderate Alzheimer’s disease. Public sources identify MEM 1003 as a small‑molecule (dihydropyridine class) L‑type calcium channel modulator intended to normalize neuronal calcium signaling — a pathophysiological mechanism implicated in AD. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Act: Key trial evidence — the registered Phase 2 study (NCT00257673) is a 12‑week, multicenter, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled trial of MEM 1003 in ~183 patients with mild–moderate AD. Preclinical work shows MEM 1003 acts as an L‑type Ca2+ channel antagonist with cognitive effects in animal models. citeturn0search2turn0search0

Web search results / sources: • Advanced drug monograph and development summary describing MEM‑1003 (mechanism: neuronal L‑type calcium channel modulator; small molecule; synonyms include BAY Z 4406). citeturn0search1 • SEC / company filings describing the Phase 2a AD trial (design, doses, and that MEM‑1003 is an L‑type calcium channel modulator). citeturn0search3 • Public trial registry / trial snapshot for NCT00257673 (trial title and 12‑week design). citeturn0search2 • News/coverage and trial results summaries reporting the Phase 2 outcome and placebo effects. citeturn0search4turn0search6 • Preclinical PubMed report showing MEM 1003 enhanced learning in aged rabbit conditioning models (L‑type Ca2+ channel antagonist activity). citeturn0search0

Reflect: Classification rationale — MEM 1003 is a small molecule whose intended pharmacologic action targets neuronal calcium channels (a proposed pathophysiological contributor to AD), so it best fits the 'disease‑targeted small molecule' category rather than a purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer or a biologic. Note: development failed to demonstrate efficacy in the cited Phase 2 trial per sources; if only symptomatic benefit without disease‑mechanism intent were described, classification might differ, but the mechanism supports 'disease‑targeted small molecule.' citeturn0search1turn0search4
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug MEM‑1003 (aka BAY Z 4406) is a small‑molecule dihydropyridine that acts as an L‑type (voltage‑gated) calcium channel modulator intended to normalize neuronal Ca2+ signaling — a mechanism linked to synaptic function, plasticity and neuronal injury. This mechanism is aimed at neuroprotection and modulation of synaptic processes rather than directly targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, or proteostasis. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Act: Key factual points extracted from the trial description and public sources: MEM‑1003 was tested in a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase 2 study in mild–moderate AD (NCT00257673). The trial listing and protocol describe MEM‑1003 as a CNS‑optimized dihydropyridine L‑type Ca2+ channel inhibitor intended to reduce pathological intracellular Ca2+ dysregulation in AD. Preclinical evidence (aged rabbit conditioning) supports L‑type Ca2+ channel antagonist activity with effects on learning. citeturn0search2turn0search4turn0search0

Reflect: CADRO mapping rationale — among CADRO categories, modulation of neuronal calcium influx primarily affects synaptic transmission, excitability and neuroprotection (i.e., processes captured by 'Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection'). Although calcium dysregulation can contribute to cell death, the described therapeutic intent (normalize signaling to protect/restore synaptic function) best matches M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection rather than H) Cell Death or J) Metabolism. If the trial description had emphasized prevention of apoptosis downstream of calcium overload as the primary mechanism, H) Cell Death could be considered; here the focus is on channel modulation to improve neuronal/synaptic function. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Web search results / supporting sources: • DrugBank entry for MEM‑1003 describing it as an investigational small molecule L‑type calcium channel modulator and noting related trial. citeturn0search1 • Clinical trial registry record for NCT00257673 (Phase 2, multicenter, randomized, placebo‑controlled study in mild–moderate AD; MEM‑1003 listed as an L‑type Ca2+ channel inhibitor). citeturn0search2 • MedPath / development monograph summarizing MEM‑1003 (BAY Z 4406) as a CNS‑optimized L‑type calcium channel modulator and noting Phase 2 outcomes. citeturn0search0 • PubMed preclinical study showing MEM‑1003 produced learning effects in aged rabbits and characterized it as an L‑type Ca2+ channel antagonist. citeturn0search4
